choices.E: It provides resilient and effective traffic flow using MPLS.
choices.B: It simplifies endpoint provisioning through standalone router management.
choices.A: It enforces a single, scalable, hub-and-spoke topology.
choices.D: It improves endpoint protection by integrating embedded and cloud security features.
choices.C: It allows configuration of application-aware policies with real time enforcement.

discussion.content: It provides job security for CCNPs

Selected Answer: CD
C and D are correct.
C and D looks OK

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of implementing a Cisco SD-WAN architecture? (Choose two.)
Which two functions is an edge node responsible for? (Choose two.)

choices.B: provides the default entry point for fabric traffic
choices.C: provides multiple entry and exit points for fabric traffic
choices.D: provides the default exit point for fabric traffic
choices.E: provides a host database that maps endpoint IDs to a current location

comments.content:
I prefer C over B because of this:
VXLAN encapsulation/de-encapsulation
Packets and frames received from endpoint... are encapsulated in fabric VXLAN and forwarded across the overlay. 
When fabric encapsulated traffic is received for the endpoint... it is de-encapsulated and sent to that endpoint.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Campus/cisco-sda-design-guide.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A 100% is correct , per book .
C is also seems right . Edge node is an xTR that provides, provides onboarding and mobility services for wired users and devices
(including fabric-enabled WLCs and APs) connected to the fabric.

Selected Answer: AB
The word "multiple" makes C not suitable.

Selected Answer: AB
It's A and B.

Straight from Cisco's training PDF - https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/m/hr_hr/training-events/2019/cisco-connect/pdf/VH-Cisco-SD-Access-Connecting.pdf

Edge Node provides first-hop services for Users / Devices connected to a Fabric

• Responsible for Identifying and Authenticating
Endpoints (e.g. Static, 802.1X, Active Directory)
• Register specific Endpoint ID info (e.g. /32 or /128)
with the Control-Plane Node(s)
• Provide an Anycast L3 Gateway for the connected
Endpoints (same IP address on all Edge nodes). 
• Performs encapsulation / de-encapsulation of data
traffic to and from all connected Endpoints

hth

Selected Answer: AB
Not sure why C is favored over B. One edge node is not providing "multiple" entry and exit points. Only the entry and exit point is true, but multiple makes it false. The default entry point is the default gateway for the clients, so B is true.

Selected Answer: AB
Going with A & B
CCNP Book: Fabric Edge Nodes
A fabric edge node provides onboarding and mobility services for wired users and devices
(including fabric-enabled WLCs and APs) connected to the fabric. It is a LISP tunnel router
(xTR) that also provides the anycast gateway, endpoint authentication..

A is clear "A fabric edge first identifies and authenticates wired endpoints (through 802.1x), in order to place them in a host pool (SVI and VRF instance) and scalable group (SGT assignment). 
Based on below i would say B is also clear:
A fabric edge provides a single Layer 3 anycast gateway (that is, the same SVI with the
same IP address on all fabric edge nodes) for its connected endpoints and also performs the
encapsulation and de-encapsulation of host traffic to and from its connected endpoints.
Not sure people are saying C, your not getting out of the fabric through an edge node... period.

comments.content: You cannot get out of the fabric directly through an edge node. Edge nodes serve as entry points into the fabric for endpoints (users, devices, IoT). However, they do not handle traffic leaving the fabric. Instead, traffic leaving is forwarded to a Border Node, which is responsible for routing traffic out of the fabric to external networks. Answer A & B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A & C are correct
i will go with A and B

Selected Answer: AB
iwill go with AB 

chrome-extension://efaidnbmnnnibpcajpcglclefindmkaj/https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2020/pdf/BRKCRS-2825.pdf
i would choose A & B. For me C could not be because not provide exit points, the exits points are edge border nodes

Selected Answer: AC
A. is definitely correct but C is explained below.
A fabric edge performs the encap and decap of host traffic to and from its connected endpoints. CCNP ENCOR Cert guide - p.623

Selected Answer: AB
Edge Node provides first-hop services for Users / Devices connected to a Fabric
[A] • Responsible for Identifying and Authenticating Endpoints (e.g. Static, 802.1X, Active Directory)
[B] • Performs encapsulation / de-encapsulation of data traffic to and from all connected Endpoints

A. fabric edge first identifies and authenticates wired
endpoints (through 802.1x), in order to place them in a

address (that is, MAC, /32 IPv4, or /128 IPv6) with the
control plane node.

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-


Guidelines
-

This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices.

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary preconfigurations have been applied.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab closes and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-

Configure logging on SW01 and NetFlow on R01 to achieve these goals:

1. Enable archive logging on SW01 to track each time a change is made to the configuration and the user who made the change.
2. The NetFlow Top Talkers feature has been preconfigured on R01. Enable the feature for all inbound traffic on interface E0/2 of R01.


R01
-

//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//



SW01
-

//IMG//

discussion.content:
SW01
conf t
archive
log config
logging enable

R01
conf t
int eth 0/2
ip flow ingress <----- no IOS version is given here so I assume post 12.2 which works well in lab
end
write mem <------------- don't forget this in any simulation 8-)

Despite reading a few sources, both can be used -one at a time on the main interface. 

R01(config-if)#ip route-cache flow ?
 <cr> <cr>
R01(config-if)#ip route-cache flow 
R01(config-if)#ip flow ingress ?
 <cr> <cr>
R01(config-if)#ip flow ingress

And, so 17.1 code contradicts what AI sources put together:

ip flow ingress and ip route-cache flow should not be used together effectively. The key differences are:

"ip route-cache flow" can only be configured on main interfaces.
"ip flow ingress" is designed for use on subinterfaces.

If you configure "ip flow ingress" on subinterfaces and then enable "ip route-cache flow" on the main interface:

The main interface configuration will overwrite the subinterface settings.
Data collection will start from the main interface and all subinterfaces

hth

comments.content:
But, for the purposes of answering the question, it should be:

!
int g0/2
R01(config-if)#ip flow ? 
 egress Enable outbound NetFlow 
 ingress Enable inbound NetFlow <----------------
 monitor Apply a Flow Monitor

"ip flow ingress" command enables NetFlow data collection on the ingress (incoming) traffic of an interface

discussion.content:
This is the description of the command from IOS:

###
LAB-SW(config-if)#ip ?
route-cache Enable fast-switching cache for outgoing packets
###

Well, the question is saying to us "ingress", so why use "route-cache" where this means "outgoing"?!
ip route-cache flow ( works only under L3 interface IP native interface )

comments.content:
Sorry the question ask: "all inbound traffic on interface E0/2 of R01"
"ip route-cache flow" and "ip flow ingress" has the same functions

discussion.content:
I try on IOS version 15.9
ip route-cache flow = ip flow ingress only on the interface
ip flow egress = outbound
ip flow ingress= inbound
So we should use command "ip flow egress" on router for monitor outbound traffic

For 1st part I'd go with (starting in global config mode):
archive
 log config
 logging enable

For 2nd part I'd go with(starting in interface config mode):
ip flow ingress

comments.content: The "ip route-cache flow" can be used only under the main interface, while the "ip flow ingress" was an enhancement to be used under subinterfaces.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which two configurations enable R1 and R2 to advertise routes into OSPF? (Choose two.)

choices.A:
R2 -
router ospf 0
network 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
network 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
choices.E:
R2 -
router ospf 0
network 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
network 172.16.2.0 255.255.255.0 area 0
choices.D:
R1 -
router ospf 0
network 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
network 192.168.2.0 0.0.0.255 area 0

discussion.content:
OSPF uses wildcard mask, NOT subnet mask.
So the correct answers are AD.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct
Btw, There is no OSPF process ID 0. OSPF process ID starts from 1. "router ospf 0" in the options must be typo.

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
Simple, in answers B,C & E, a network mask is used instead of a wildcard mask. 
A & D are remaining.
answers are correct

i think correct A&D
Traffic policing propagates bursts. When the traffic rate reaches the configured maximum rate (or committed information rate), excess traffic is dropped (or remarked). The result is an output rate that appears as a saw-tooth with crests and troughs.
Unlike traffic shaping, traffic policing does not cause delay.
Classification (which includes traffic policing, traffic shaping and queuing techniques) should take place at the network edge. It is recommended that classification occur as close to the source of the traffic as possible.

Selected Answer: AD
when I see policing, i normally consider the way police handle things, they always go direct to the responsible person (closer to the source) and not at police station (destination)

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct
Provided answers are correct

A and D

answers are correct

AD correct,

questions.question_text:
An engineer is describing QoS to a client.
Which two facts apply to traffic policing? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Policing drops traffic that exceeds the defined rate.
choices.E: Policing typically delays the traffic, rather than drops it.
choices.C: Policing should be performed as close to the destination as possible.
choices.A: Policing should be performed as close to the source as possible.
choices.B: Policing adapts to network congestion by queuing excess traffic.
